title: Why did hospitals have these frogs in their supply rooms? - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What unique feature do African clawed frogs possess that makes them special for scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to jump long distances.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to change color to blend into their surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to live on land and in water.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to fly.

multiple-choice.question: What hormone is responsible for triggering ovulation in African clawed frogs?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG).

options.label: B
options.text: Pituitary hormone.

options.label: C
options.text: Ovarian hormone.

options.label: D
options.text: Testosterone.

multiple-choice.question: Why were African clawed frogs used in pregnancy tests in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they could detect hCG in human urine quickly and accurately.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they could detect hCG in human urine after multiple days of injections.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were abundant and easy to find.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were the only animals that could detect hCG.

multiple-choice.question: What was the major drawback of using animals like mice and rabbits in pregnancy tests before the discovery of African clawed frogs?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too expensive to use.

options.label: B
options.text: They required multiple days of injections and dissection.

options.label: C
options.text: They were not accurate in detecting hCG.

options.label: D
options.text: They were not available in large numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What made African clawed frogs ideal for use in numerous scientific studies?

options.label: A
options.text: Their slow development and limited egg production.

options.label: B
options.text: Their rapid development and ability to produce eggs in any season.

options.label: C
options.text: Their small size and ease of handling.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to live on land and in water.

multiple-choice.question: What has been a negative consequence of the widespread use of African clawed frogs in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: The extinction of multiple frog species due to the chytrid fungus.

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction of a new species that has helped native amphibians.

options.label: C
options.text: The development of new medicines and treatments.

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of new jobs in the scientific community.

multiple-choice.question: Why are African clawed frogs now classified as an invasive species in many regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are native to those regions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have outcompeted native amphibians and carried a deadly fungus.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too abundant and easy to find.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are no longer needed for scientific research.

multiple-choice.question: What was the breakthrough discovery made by Hillel Shapiro, Harry Zwarenstein, and Lancelot Hogben in the 1920s?

options.label: A
options.text: The discovery of the chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG).

options.label: B
options.text: The discovery of the pituitary gland's role in color changing in African clawed frogs.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of the ability of African clawed frogs to detect hCG in human urine.

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of the use of ox hormone to trigger ovulation in African clawed frogs.

multiple-choice.question: What eventually replaced African clawed frogs in pregnancy tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical tests that detected hCG directly.

options.label: B
options.text: Animal tests using mice and rabbits.

options.label: C
options.text: Plant-based tests that detected hCG.

options.label: D
options.text: Microbial tests that detected hCG.

multiple-choice.question: What unique feature of African clawed frogs' skin helps them to catch prey?

options.label: A
options.text: Their smooth skin can quickly change color to blend into their surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: Their rough skin can detect vibrations in the water.

options.label: C
options.text: Their skin has a sticky substance that traps prey.

options.label: D
options.text: Their skin has a reflective surface that attracts prey.

title: Why is this black square famous? - Allison Leigh

multiple-choice.question: Where did an exhibition of radical artworks, featuring Kazimir Malevich's "Black Square," open on December 19th, 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: Moscow, Russia

options.label: B
options.text: St. Petersburg, Russia

options.label: C
options.text: Kiev, Ukraine

options.label: D
options.text: Warsaw, Poland

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial reaction of some attendees to Kazimir Malevich's "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: They praised its simplicity and innovation.

options.label: B
options.text: They were indifferent to the painting.

options.label: C
options.text: They scoffed at the painting's simplicity, claiming that even a child could have done it.

options.label: D
options.text: They praised its technical skill and realism.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the central form in Kazimir Malevich's "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is perfectly black and perfectly square.

options.label: B
options.text: It is neither perfectly black nor perfectly square.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a perfect circle.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a perfect triangle.

multiple-choice.question: What does technical analysis of "Black Square" reveal about the canvas?

options.label: A
options.text: It was used only for this painting.

options.label: B
options.text: It was used for two other paintings before "Black Square."

options.label: C
options.text: It was used for five other paintings before "Black Square."

options.label: D
options.text: It was used for ten other paintings before "Black Square."

multiple-choice.question: What style of art did Kazimir Malevich pioneer with "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: Impressionism

options.label: B
options.text: Post-Impressionism

options.label: C
options.text: Futurism

options.label: D
options.text: Suprematism

multiple-choice.question: What was Kazimir Malevich's goal with Suprematism?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new style of abstract art.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new style of representational art.

options.label: C
options.text: To make feeling the substance of his work.

options.label: D
options.text: To make objects the substance of his work.

multiple-choice.question: How did Kazimir Malevich's artistic style change after Stalin's rise to power in the 1920s?

options.label: A
options.text: He continued to produce avant-garde art.

options.label: B
options.text: He returned to figuration, painting peasants standing robotically in barren spaces.

options.label: C
options.text: He stopped producing art altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: He began producing art that celebrated Soviet leaders and heroic workers.

multiple-choice.question: What symbol did Kazimir Malevich include in his self-portrait, indicating that he had not abandoned Suprematism completely?

options.label: A
options.text: A red square

options.label: B
options.text: A black circle

options.label: C
options.text: A tiny black square

options.label: D
options.text: A blue triangle

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Kazimir Malevich's "Black Square" in the context of art history?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked a return to traditional representational art.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked a breakthrough in the development of abstract art.

options.label: C
options.text: It marked a departure from the world of objects and the beginning of non-objectivity.

options.label: D
options.text: It marked the end of the avant-garde movement.

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate goal of Kazimir Malevich's artistic movement, Suprematism?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new style of art that celebrated Soviet leaders and heroic workers.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new style of art that was focused on depicting real-world objects.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a refuge of pure feeling that lay beyond the burden of objects and the suffering of a divided world.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new style of art that was focused on technical skill and realism.

title: What the fossil fuel industry doesn't want you to know - Al Gore

options.text: Unrelenting opposition from the fossil fuel industry

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: It is not yet available

According to the speaker, what is the primary reason why fossil fuel companies are not sincere actors in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: B

title: Can you change your sleep schedule?

multiple-choice.question: What determines a person's natural sleep schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: Their daily routine and habits.

options.label: B
options.text: Their genetic makeup and birth time.

options.label: C
options.text: Their circadian system, which responds to light exposure.

options.label: D
options.text: Their lifestyle and environment.

multiple-choice.question: Where are the nerve cell clusters that anchor the circadian system located?

options.label: A
options.text: In the posterior hypothalamus.

options.label: B
options.text: In the anterior hypothalamus.

options.label: C
options.text: In the brain stem.

options.label: D
options.text: In the spinal cord.

multiple-choice.question: What helps the circadian system track the day-night cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: The body's internal temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: The body's hormone levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Light exposure coming in through the eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: The body's physical activity levels.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of melatonin in the circadian system?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: To induce sleepiness.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase alertness.

options.label: D
options.text: To suppress appetite.

multiple-choice.question: Can a person change their circadian rhythm by sticking to a strict schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, completely.

options.label: B
options.text: To a degree, but it depends on individual factors.

options.label: C
options.text: No, it's fixed at birth.

options.label: D
options.text: Only with medication.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of inconsistent sleeping habits on the circadian system?

options.label: A
options.text: It strengthens the circadian system.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the circadian system.

options.label: C
options.text: It weakens the circadian system.

options.label: D
options.text: It reverses the circadian system.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to get sufficient contrast between bright daylight and dimmer nighttime light?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: To improve sleep quality.

options.label: C
options.text: To synchronize the circadian rhythm.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase alertness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of getting outside in the morning to expose yourself to sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps you fall asleep faster.

options.label: B
options.text: It improves your mood.

options.label: C
options.text: It teaches your body when to be active and alert.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases your appetite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important factor in maintaining a healthy sleep schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: Going to bed at the same time every night.

options.label: B
options.text: Waking up at the same time every morning.

options.label: C
options.text: Getting enough rest for the day ahead.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding caffeine and electronics before bedtime.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the transcript regarding sleep schedules?

options.label: A
options.text: That everyone should be an early bird.

options.label: B
options.text: That everyone should be a night owl.

options.label: C
options.text: That there's no wrong time to wake up or go to sleep as long as you're consistent.

options.label: D
options.text: That sleep schedules are fixed at birth.

title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is long COVID, and how is it defined?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition that occurs immediately after COVID-19 infection and lasts for 1-2 weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that occurs 4 weeks to 3 months after COVID-19 infection and has devastating effects on a patient's quality of life.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that occurs only in older adults and is characterized by mild symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that occurs only in young children and is characterized by severe symptoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is epigenetics, and how does it relate to genetic information?

options.label: A
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of genetic mutations and their effects on gene expression.

options.label: B
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how environmental factors affect gene expression.

options.label: C
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how cells modulate genetic information without changing the sequence of DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how viruses affect gene expression.

multiple-choice.question: What is DNA methylation, and how does it affect gene expression?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that adds a tag to a gene to increase its expression.

options.label: B
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that adds a tag to a gene to decrease its expression.

options.label: C
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that removes a tag from a gene to increase its expression.

options.label: D
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that removes a tag from a gene to decrease its expression.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Swedish study, what genes were found to have changes in methylation after COVID-19 infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Genes involved in regulating ACE2, histamine signaling, and taste and smell.

options.label: B
options.text: Genes involved in regulating inflammation, immune response, and cardiovascular events.

options.label: C
options.text: Genes involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and survival.

options.label: D
options.text: Genes involved in regulating metabolism, energy production, and mitochondrial function.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main finding of the US-based study on DNA methylation and long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: The study found no difference in methylation between people with long COVID and people in remission.

options.label: B
options.text: The study found changes in DNA methylation that persisted after infection, but in different genes than the Swedish study.

options.label: C
options.text: The study found changes in DNA methylation that were associated with increased cardiovascular events.

options.label: D
options.text: The study found changes in DNA methylation that were associated with decreased inflammation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential link between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Both conditions are caused by the same virus.

options.label: B
options.text: Both conditions are characterized by similar symptoms, such as fatigue and muscle pain.

options.label: C
options.text: Both conditions are associated with changes in DNA methylation and epigenetic signals.

options.label: D
options.text: Both conditions are treated with the same medications.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the finding that patients with long COVID had similar self-antibodies to patients with chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that long COVID is caused by an autoimmune response.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that chronic fatigue syndrome is caused by a viral infection.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that both conditions are associated with changes in the immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that both conditions are treated with the same medications.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of studying epigenetic changes in long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for the condition.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the underlying mechanisms of the condition.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify biomarkers for the condition.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new diagnostic tests for the condition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of understanding the link between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to the development of new treatments for both conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: It could lead to a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms of both conditions.

options.label: C
options.text: It could lead to the identification of new biomarkers for both conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: It could lead to the development of new diagnostic tests for both conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the video regarding long COVID and epigenetics?

options.label: A
options.text: Long COVID is a condition that is not well understood, and more research is needed to understand its underlying mechanisms.

options.label: B
options.text: Epigenetics plays a crucial role in understanding the underlying mechanisms of long COVID.

options.label: C
options.text: Long COVID is a condition that is caused by changes in DNA methylation and epigenetic signals.

options.label: D
options.text: More research is needed to understand the link between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome.

title: The one thing stopping jellyfish from taking over - Mariela Pajuelo & Javier Antonio Quinones

options.text: They have been remaining stable.

options.label: C
options.text: They have been increasing and overwhelming the oceans.

options.label: B

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is "flow" in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A state of complete relaxation and reduced productivity.

options.label: B
options.text: A state of heightened anxiety and increased self-judgment.

options.label: C
options.text: A unique mental state of effortless engagement and increased productivity.

options.label: D
options.text: A state of complete distraction and decreased focus.

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what are some benefits of experiencing flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased procrastination, decreased creativity, and lower levels of positive emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: Higher levels of positive emotions, creativity, and feelings of accomplishment.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased productivity, enhanced learning, and academic achievement.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased worry, self-judgment, and distraction.

multiple-choice.question: What is one defining feature of flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeling easily distracted and unable to focus.

options.label: B
options.text: Feeling effortlessly engaged in a task and losing track of time.

options.label: C
options.text: Feeling anxious and self-conscious about one's performance.

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling bored and unchallenged by a task.

multiple-choice.question: According to brain imaging studies, what changes occur in the brain during flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased activity in regions involved in attention, self-awareness, and self-consciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased activity in regions involved in attention, self-awareness, and self-consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in neural activity in regions involved in attention, self-awareness, and self-consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: No changes in neural activity occur during flow.

multiple-choice.question: What type of activities are more likely to elicit flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Activities that are extrinsically motivating, such as doing chores for money.

options.label: B
options.text: Activities that are intrinsically motivating, such as participating in a favorite hobby.

options.label: C
options.text: Activities that are physically demanding, such as sports.

options.label: D
options.text: Activities that are mentally demanding, such as solving complex math problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ideal balance for finding flow?

options.label: A
options.text: A task that is too easy and requires little skill.

options.label: B
options.text: A task that is too challenging and requires high skill.

options.label: C
options.text: A task that balances personal skill level with the activity's challenge.

options.label: D
options.text: A task that is completely unpredictable and lacks clear goals.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often find flow when playing games of chance?

options.label: A
options.text: Because games of chance require high skill and strategy.

options.label: B
options.text: Because games of chance provide moment-to-moment feedback and clear goals.

options.label: C
options.text: Because games of chance are intrinsically motivating and enjoyable.

options.label: D
options.text: Because games of chance are physically demanding and require quick reflexes.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to increase your chances of finding flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Find a noisy environment with many distractions.

options.label: B
options.text: Break tasks into large, complex segments that are difficult to track.

options.label: C
options.text: Set unclear end goals that are frustratingly challenging.

options.label: D
options.text: Find a quiet environment, break tasks into small segments, and set clear end goals.

multiple-choice.question: What should you avoid doing when trying to find flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing too much on reaching flow.

options.label: B
options.text: Setting clear end goals and tracking progress.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding a quiet environment and minimizing distractions.

options.label: D
options.text: Breaking tasks into small, manageable segments.

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what is still not fully understood about flow?

options.label: A
options.text: How flow compares to other states of consciousness, such as meditation.

options.label: B
options.text: How flow affects productivity and learning.

options.label: C
options.text: How flow is related to creativity and positive emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: How flow is affected by physical activity and exercise.

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is geoengineering, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: Geoengineering is the study of the Earth's natural systems, with the goal of understanding climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: Geoengineering is a class of deliberate, large-scale interventions in the Earth's natural systems, intended to help restrain climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: Geoengineering is a type of renewable energy source, aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: Geoengineering is a form of climate change denial, aimed at discrediting scientific research.

multiple-choice.question: What category of geoengineering involves blocking the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Solar radiation management

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon capture and storage

options.label: C
options.text: Climate change mitigation

options.label: D
options.text: Weather modification

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a geoengineering proposal that involves enhancing natural cooling systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a giant sunshade in Earth's orbit

options.label: B
options.text: Enlarging marine clouds to reflect more sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a massive volcanic plume to block sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: Developing a new form of renewable energy

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential risk of solar radiation management?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: It could cause extreme weather events or crop failures in certain regions.

options.label: C
options.text: It could result in a rapid decrease in global temperatures.

options.label: D
options.text: It could have no impact on the global climate.

multiple-choice.question: Why do some scientists believe that geoengineering should be studied, despite its risks?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a proven solution to climate change

options.label: B
options.text: Because it could be a last resort in desperate times

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a cheap and easy solution to implement

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has no potential risks or side effects

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an unintended geoengineering project?

options.label: A
options.text: The construction of a massive solar panel array

options.label: B
options.text: The development of a new form of renewable energy

options.label: C
options.text: The emissions generated from centuries of burning fossil fuels

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of a giant sunshade in Earth's orbit

multiple-choice.question: What could happen if a rogue actor were to implement a geoengineering plan without governmental approval?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: It could result in a rapid decrease in global temperatures.

options.label: C
options.text: It could cause unintended and potentially disastrous consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: It could have no impact on the global climate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important reason to investigate the impacts of geoengineering, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a proven solution to climate change

options.label: B
options.text: Because it could be a last resort in desperate times

options.label: C
options.text: Because people are already making large-scale interventions in the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a cheap and easy solution to implement
